text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SABAH
- Members of Islamic sects in the political establishment are working to keep the government on its feet.
- Turk Cypriot tycoon Asil Nadir in $2 billion bid to sue British authorities.
MILLIYET
- An investigation into a fiery Islamist speech by one of his MPs puts Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan in an awkward position.
- Price of individual food products have gone up by between 50-400 percent since Erbakan came to office last year.
HURRIYET
- National Security Council meeting today will discuss provocative Islamist speech by Welfare deputy Sevki Yilmaz.
- Legal challenge to attempt to build a new terminal at Istanbul airport.
YENI YUZYIL
- Opposition accuses Erbakan's Welfare Party of earning money from the illegal construction of buildings in Istanbul.
- The business community wants to see a new elections law that would hinder the Islamists before any new polls are called.
RADIKAL
- Coalition partners look favourably on early elections in November.
- The Istanbul stock exchange jumps by 65 points despite prospects of early elections.
DUNYA
- Asil Nadir aims to make a business comeback in the southeast of Turkey and Central Asia.
ZAMAN
- Erbakan apologises for the behaviour of Islamist firebrand Yilmaz.
CUMHURIYET
- The army will take Erbakan to task at security council meeting for not complying with anti-Islamist crackdown.
